title: Toy rocket with an initial non-linear acceleration

content.question: Read each question carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. A toy rocket of mass <math alttext="0.50 kilogram " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.50</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>k</mi><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> starts from rest on the ground and is launched upward, experiencing a vertical net force. The rocket’s upward acceleration <math alttext="a" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for the first 6 seconds is given by the equation <math alttext="a, equals K minus, L times t squared " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mi>a</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>K</mi><mo>−</mo><mi>L</mi><msup><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>,</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> where <math alttext="K equals, 9.0 meters per second squared " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>K</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>9.0</mn><mrow><mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mrow><mo>/</mo><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>s</mtext></mrow><mrow><mtext>2</mtext></mrow></msup></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="L equals, 0.25 meter per second to the fourth power" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.25</mn><mrow><mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mrow><mo>/</mo><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>s</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is the time in seconds. At <math alttext="t equals 6.0 seconds " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>, the fuel is exhausted and the rocket is under the influence of gravity alone. Assume air resistance and the rocket’s change in mass are negligible. (a) Calculate the magnitude of the net impulse exerted on the rocket from <math alttext="t equals 0 " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="t equals 6.0 seconds " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>.

frqParts.text: Read each question carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. A toy rocket of mass <math alttext="0.50 kilogram " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.50</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>k</mi><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> starts from rest on the ground and is launched upward, experiencing a vertical net force. The rocket’s upward acceleration <math alttext="a" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for the first 6 seconds is given by the equation <math alttext="a, equals K minus, L times t squared " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mi>a</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>K</mi><mo>−</mo><mi>L</mi><msup><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>,</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> where <math alttext="K equals, 9.0 meters per second squared " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>K</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>9.0</mn><mrow><mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mrow><mo>/</mo><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>s</mtext></mrow><mrow><mtext>2</mtext></mrow></msup></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="L equals, 0.25 meter per second to the fourth power" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.25</mn><mrow><mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mrow><mo>/</mo><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>s</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is the time in seconds. At <math alttext="t equals 6.0 seconds " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>, the fuel is exhausted and the rocket is under the influence of gravity alone. Assume air resistance and the rocket’s change in mass are negligible. (a) Calculate the magnitude of the net impulse exerted on the rocket from <math alttext="t equals 0 " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="t equals 6.0 seconds " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(b) Calculate the speed of the rocket at <math alttext="t equals 6.0 seconds " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(c) i. Calculate the kinetic energy of the rocket at <math alttext="t equals 6.0 seconds " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>.

ii. Calculate the change in gravitational potential energy of the rocket-Earth system from <math alttext="t equals 0 " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="t equals 6.0 seconds " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>.
(d) Calculate the maximum height reached by the rocket relative to its launching point.

(e) On the axes below, assuming the upward direction to be positive, sketch a graph of the velocity <math alttext="v" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of the rocket as a function of time <math alttext="t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> from the time the rocket is launched to the time it returns to the ground. <math alttext="uppercase T sub top " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>T</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>t</mi><mi>o</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> represents the time the rocket reaches its maximum height. Explicitly label the maxima with numerical values or algebraic expressions, as appropriate.

skill.text: 1.C: Create qualitative sketches of graphs that represent features of a model or the behavior of a physical system.
